questions.question: What were the main pillars of British administration in India?
questions.answer: Civil Services, military, police force, and judicial system.

questions.question: Who introduced bureaucracy (Civil Services) in India?
questions.answer: Lord Cornwallis.

questions.question: What was the role of the District Collector?
questions.answer: He was responsible for revenue collection, giving justice, and maintaining law and order in the district.

questions.question: How were officers appointed in the Indian Civil Services (ICS)?
questions.answer: Through competitive examinations.

questions.question: What were the duties of the military under British rule?
questions.answer: To safeguard British-occupied regions, acquire new territories, and suppress revolts.

questions.question: What was the duty of the police force?
questions.answer: To maintain law and order in the country.

questions.question: On what basis did the British establish a new judicial system in India?
questions.answer: On the basis of the judicial system in England.

questions.question: What courts were established in each district?
questions.answer: Civil and Criminal Courts.

questions.question: What principle did the Indian Penal Code enforce?
questions.answer: The principle of equality before law.

questions.question: Who led the committee to create the code of law?
questions.answer: Lord Macaulay.

questions.question: What was one defect of the new judicial system?
questions.answer: There were separate courts and different laws for Europeans.

questions.question: How did the British economic policies differ from previous invaders?
questions.answer: Previous invaders were absorbed into Indian culture and didn't change the economic system, but the British imposed an economic system beneficial to England.

questions.question: What was the main source of state income in pre-British India?
questions.answer: Land revenue.

questions.question: How was revenue collected in the pre-British period?
questions.answer: Mainly in the form of grains, and it was based on the type of crop cultivated.

questions.question: What changes did the British make in the land revenue system?
questions.answer: Land was measured, tax was fixed per area, payment was in cash, and land could be confiscated for non-payment.

questions.question: What were the consequences of the new land revenue system on farmers?
questions.answer: Farmers had to sell crops at low prices, mortgage land to moneylenders, and many became bankrupt.

questions.question: Who exploited the Indian farmers under the British system?
questions.answer: The government, zamindars, moneylenders, and merchants.

questions.question: What is commercialisation of agriculture?
questions.answer: The process of giving stress on cultivation of profit-giving cash crops instead of food grains.

questions.question: Give two examples of cash crops encouraged by the British.
questions.answer: Cotton and indigo (also tobacco, tea, etc.).

questions.question: What period did India face great famines?
questions.answer: From 1860 to 1900.

questions.question: In which year did the first railway run in India and on which route?
questions.answer: In 1853, from Mumbai to Thane.

questions.question: What communication system did the British start in India in 1853?
questions.answer: The Telegraph system.

questions.question: What was the impact of transport and communication development on Indians?
questions.answer: It increased the sense of unity among them.

questions.question: Why did traditional Indian industries decline under British rule?
questions.answer: Because of high taxes on Indian exports, low taxes on British imports, and competition from cheap machine-made British goods.

questions.question: Who started the first textile mill in Mumbai and when?
questions.answer: Kawasjee Nanabhoy Davar in 1854.

questions.question: Where and when was the first jute mill started in India?
questions.answer: At Rishra in Bengal in 1855.

questions.question: Who established the Tata Iron and Steel Company and where?
questions.answer: Jamshedji Tata established it at Jamshedpur in 1907.

questions.question: What society did Sir William Jones establish in Kolkata and in which year?
questions.answer: The Asiatic Society of Bengal in 1784.

questions.question: Who was Max Mueller?
questions.answer: A German thinker and scholar of Indian religion, language, and history.

questions.question: Which act prohibited Sati and who passed it?
questions.answer: The Sati Prohibition Act was passed by Lord William Bentinck in 1829.

questions.question: Which act allowed widow remarriage and who passed it?
questions.answer: The Widow Remarriage Act was passed by Lord Dalhousie in 1856.

questions.question: When did English education start being imparted in India and on whose recommendation?
questions.answer: In 1835, on the recommendation of Lord Macaulay.

questions.question: In which year were universities established in Kolkata, Mumbai, and Madras?
Which class led the social reform movement in India?
questions.answer: The Western-educated middle class.

questions.question: What values shaped the new era in 19th-century Europe?
questions.answer: Humanitarianism, democracy, nationalism, and liberalism.

questions.question: Why did the British study Indian tradition, history, and literature?
questions.answer: To understand Indian society for carrying out administration.

questions.question: What were some of the development works carried out by Chhatrapati Pratapsingh in Satara?
questions.answer: He built a water tank, roads, planted trees, built schools, set up a printing press, and built a road from Satara to Mahabaleshwar.

questions.question: What book on polity was printed in 1827 during Chhatrapati Pratapsingh's rule?
questions.answer: The book 'Sabhaniti'.

questions.question: What was the impact of the dual government system on Bengal?
questions.answer: Money from taxes went to company officers, and the Nawab was unable to maintain law and order effectively.

questions.question: How did the British Parliament try to control the East India Company?
questions.answer: By passing acts like the Regulating Act (1773), Pitt's India Act (1784), and others in 1813, 1833, and 1853.

questions.question: What did Lord Cornwallis do to restrict private trade by company officers?
questions.answer: He increased their salaries to reduce corruption.

questions.question: What was the purpose of the Board of Control set up by Pitt's India Act?
questions.answer: To regulate and manage the affairs of the East India Company in India.

questions.question: Why was the Indian Penal Code difficult for common people?
questions.answer: Because the new laws were complex and not easily understood.

questions.question: How did the British land revenue policy affect the village economic system?
questions.answer: It destroyed the self-sufficient village economy by forcing cash payments and leading to land alienation.

questions.question: Why did Indian artisans find it difficult to compete with British goods?
questions.answer: Because British goods were machine-made, produced in large quantities at low cost, and had favorable tax treatment.

questions.question: What were some new industries that developed in India under British rule?
questions.answer: Textile, jute, iron and steel, coal, metals, sugar, cement, and chemical industries.

questions.question: What was the role of the Asiatic Society of Bengal?
questions.answer: To study Indian tradition, history, literature, music, and flora-fauna.

questions.question: How did Western education influence Indian society?
questions.answer: It introduced Indians to Western thoughts, modern reforms, science, and technology, leading to social reform movements.

questions.question: What was the condition of law in India before British rule?
questions.answer: It differed from place to place and there was discrimination based on casteism.

questions.question: What was the difference in tax treatment between Indian exports and British imports?
questions.answer: High taxes on Indian exports to England and very low taxes on British imports to India.

questions.question: Why did the British develop transport and communication in India?
questions.answer: For increase in trade and convenience of administration.

questions.question: What was the impact of commercialisation of agriculture on food security?
questions.answer: It led to neglect of food grains, contributing to famines.

questions.question: How did the British police force differ from traditional systems?
questions.answer: It was a centralized force responsible for law and order, unlike traditional community-based systems.

questions.question: What was the effect of the British judicial system on pending cases?
questions.answer: Cases remained pending for years due to complex procedures and expensive legal processes.

questions.question: Why did the British encourage cash crops in India?
questions.answer: To serve the industrial needs of Britain and generate higher revenue.

questions.question: How did the British land revenue system vary across regions?
questions.answer: Different systems like Zamindari, Ryotwari, and Mahalwari were implemented in different regions.

questions.question: What was the economic condition of England that influenced its policies in India?
questions.answer: England was a modern capitalist nation due to the Industrial Revolution.

questions.question: Why did the British need English-educated Indians?
questions.answer: To assist in administration and act as intermediaries between the rulers and the ruled.

questions.question: What was the impact of the British military on Indian states?
questions.answer: It was used to conquer territories and suppress any resistance or revolt.

questions.question: How did the British policy of equality before law have defects?
questions.answer: Because in practice, Europeans had separate courts and often received favorable treatment.

questions.question: What was the fate of Chhatrapati Pratapsingh's kingdom?
questions.answer: It was annexed by the British in 1848 under the Doctrine of Lapse.

questions.question: What was the significance of the Treaty of Salbai?
questions.answer: It ended the First Anglo-Maratha War and restored territories to the Marathas.

questions.question: How did the Subsidiary Alliance affect Indian rulers' sovereignty?
questions.answer: They lost their independence and became dependent on the British for protection.

questions.question: What was the result of the Second Anglo-Maratha War?
questions.answer: Increased British interference in Maratha states and further loss of Maratha power.

questions.question: Why did Raghunathrao seek British help?
questions.answer: Due to his greed for the Peshwaship after the death of Peshwa Madhavrao.

questions.question: What was the British strategy in dealing with the Marathas?
questions.answer: To exploit internal divisions and sign treaties like the Subsidiary Alliance to gain control.

questions.question: How did the British manage to defeat the Marathas?
questions.answer: By winning key battles, using diplomacy, and exploiting disunity among Maratha chiefs.

questions.question: What was the role of the District Collector in revenue collection?
questions.answer: He was the chief revenue officer of the district, responsible for assessing and collecting land tax.

questions.question: What was the impact of the British postal system?
questions.answer: It improved communication across the country and facilitated administration and trade.

questions.question: How did the British use the telegraph system?
questions.answer: To connect cities and military stations for quick communication and control.

questions.question: What was the condition of Indian agriculture before British rule?
questions.answer: It was self-sufficient, with revenue based on crop type and collected in kind, and farmers were protected in case of crop failure.

questions.question: How did the British revenue policy lead to farmer indebtedness?
questions.answer: Forced cash payments and high taxes led farmers to borrow from moneylenders at high interest rates.

questions.question: What was the response of the British government to famines in India?
questions.answer: They did not take effective measures to relieve famine and spent little on irrigation or relief.

questions.question: What was the effect of the decline of traditional industries on artisans?
questions.answer: Many artisans became unemployed and were forced into poverty.

questions.question: How did the establishment of universities in 1857 impact India?
questions.answer: It promoted higher education and created a class of Indian intellectuals exposed to Western ideas.

questions.question: What was the significance of the Sati Prohibition Act?
questions.answer: It was a major social reform that outlawed the practice of Sati (widow burning).

questions.question: What was the overall impact of British rule on India's economy?
questions.answer: It led to economic exploitation, deindustrialization, and transformation into a supplier of raw materials and a market for British goods.
